conversion_verification.notes: Second image is a true 3D cutaway: walls have height/thickness, multiple faces per wall are visible, and interior volume is readable from an elevated angled view.

3d_conversion_fundamentals.notes: Clear 3D extrusion with readable wall corners and room volume; cutaway is clean. View is slightly near-top-down but still angled and spatial.

geometric_accuracy.notes: Overall zoning roughly matches (large living/dining left/center, kitchen/playroom right, small service rooms + stairs top). However, several boundary shapes/proportions differ and a prominent bottom-center stair/entry massing appears that does not match the 2D plan's main entry configuration. Some internal partitions (pantry/half-bath/closets) look simplified or shifted.

interior_elements.notes: Kitchen counters/island, dining table, seating, and bathroom fixtures are present. Some furniture appears inconsistent with room identities from the plan (e.g., bed-like object in the main open area) and placement/orientation is only partially faithful.

visual_clarity.notes: Walls/floors/openings are distinguishable with good contrast and minimal artifacts. Lighting is adequate and the background is clean; minor ambiguity remains due to near-top-down angle and simplified openings.

detected_errors.description: Noticeable layout/proportion deviations versus the 2D plan, including mismatched boundary shapes and an added/altered bottom-center stair/entry configuration.
Several door/window placements and opening proportions appear simplified and do not clearly align with the 2D plan walls.
Furniture/room identity mapping is imperfect (some items appear in rooms not indicated by the 2D layout).

summary: A genuine 3D cutaway was produced with strong 3D fundamentals, but only moderate geometric fidelity to the original floor plan due to shifted/altered partitions, proportions, and entry/stair features.
